p.span: Abuse is so prevalent and so destructive that it get’s it’s own separate category. It is not a psychological tendency as being abusive is an attitude problem. People that are abusive do so selectively and they can turn it on and off at will.

span.style: font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;
font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;

p.span: Abuse is poorly understood and often misunderstood by people who are not well documented on it. It takes great many forms and it can be from overt to expertly subtle. It can be from illegal (such as domestic violence) to impossible to prove in court but just as destructive.

span.style: font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;
font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;

p.span: A definition of abuse found in Lundy Bancroft’s book which stuck with me is: “Abuse is the opposite of respect. You do not abuse those you respect and you do not respect those who you abuse. ”

span.style: font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;
font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;

p.span: Abuse infringes on basic human dignity as put forth in the UN’s Universal Declaration of Human Rights. It is not limited to relationships, indeed the tactics a dictator may use to maintain power over a nation are disturbingly similar to the tactics an abuser inside a relationship would use.

p.span: Abuse can have many forms. Covert or overt, direct, indirect, through the environment, physical, emotional. It is important for us to understand that abuse is not just husband beating his wife, and that in all it’s forms abusive tendencies is much more common than we would think, and that the perpetrators are not always men. A must read for any person serious about forming a long term relationship.
